Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2010 06:51PM nene2059 wrote: Girls let me tell you I totally understand the feelings about fertility.  My husband and I were already pushing forward on that front when I was diagnosed.  We got married at 32, first time married for both, and decided to wait a year and then start the family.  It had been three years of frustratingly normal fertility test results.  Each of us were completely normal and healthy in that respect.  I went on a fertility med, Clomid, which just guarantees ovulation, for about six months and nada, nothing. Then along came BC.  I wonder if the Clomid did not speed up the BC process even though my BS said no.  Any way we did see a fertility specialist after diagnosis and I went on Lupron to "protect" my ovaries from the chemo by shutting them down during the treatments.  There was no guarantee but it was the only option I was comfortable with.  I did not want to put chemo off until eggs could be harvested and I was not willing to go through the hormones that would take with hormone + BC.  I went through all that only to find out when it was time to take Tamoxifen and hopefully be off to my new life after cancer that I was a poor metabolizer of Tamox and I needed to have my ovaries removed.  WOW.  Talk about devastated.  I did what I had to do and I have been to many baby showers and have basked in the glow of pregnant friends many times since. I have gotten to the point that I am just happy for them and not unhappy for me.  It took a while.  Being pregnant to have children is just something that we take for granted I guess.  When I was little it never would have occurred to me that I would never be pregnant.  I will, however, be a mom and we go to our adoption orientation tomorrow.  My hubby just wants me to be healthy and to be around to be with him.  I love him for that but also feel guilty that I took away his biological option.  It cushioned the blow that we had not been succesful in conceiving and that we were 36 and only had about 6 more years where it would even be advisable to try to have our own biological baby.  You both are under 30 and have many more years of possible fertility.  Healthy babies have and will be conceived after chemo.  A wise women on these boards told me one day, after I had found out about the ovary removal, that children grow in your heart or under it they are both the same.  We venture off tomorrow to begin the quest to "meet" our children and have them grow in our hearts.  Best of luck to you all and cheers to a great life and the family of our choosing after BC.
Posts.Title: Is anybody else as young as i am? sumby nmiller

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 06:37PM nene2059 wrote: Hey Sumby.  I was diagnosed a year ago today at the age of 36.  I know that at 27 that probably sounds old but we are both considered really young for BC.  I now know lots of women under 40 that have been diagnosed.  I did a fashion show for a BC group and I was standing with 4 other women and were shocked to find out that we had been diagnosed at 28, 32, 36, and 38.  This was not just a young survivors group.  I had no reason to be worried getting BC and when I found the lump I was told by all my friends that it had to be caffeine.  No such luck.  Check out young survival coalition like the other ladies have suggested and know that you are not alone.  You will be an inspiration to others......look you already are.  Be well and take great care of yourself.  You have a wonderful future, one day at a time, in front of you.
Posts.Title: Is anybody else as young as i am? sumby nmiller

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2010 07:19PM nene2059 wrote:
Posts.Title: Is anybody else as young as i am? sumby nmiller

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2009 07:18PM nene2059 wrote: Hi bubbly. I also was 36 when I found my lump.  I can honestly say I believed that it was nothing until I went for the mammogram and the hospital called my doctor to order an ultrasound that same day and then sent me to see her (same day) so that she could schedule me with a surgeon to get a biopsy.  Unfortunately, for me, it was not a fibriod or caused from caffeine which is what all my girlfriends were telling me.  It was breast cancer BUT let me reiterate that most lumps are not cancerous and I have all the faith in the world that yours will be fine.  I turned 37 during treatment.  Definitely take family or friends with you to all appointments as they will be extra sets of ears and  can ask questions.  They can also celebrate with you when you here that it is benign:) If the worst is confirmed then know that the treatments are very powerful and this is a great community for support.  Take care and I wish you the best.

Posts.Title: River is an Angel now. Fitztwins susanmary

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 06:16PM - edited Oct 29, 2009 06:19PM by nene2059 Hi everyone.  I was not stage III but I saw this on the active threads and thought I could add something that may help alleviate the fears of the poster who was worried if she got the right chemo or if ac and taxol work on hr+ BC.  I had bilateral BC.  I felt a lump in my right breast and at 36 was sure it had to be a fibroid.  We all know the rest of this story.  It was stage 2a IDC and another separate IDC was found in the left breast.  This one was about 1.6cm and considered stage 1 when I was clinically staged because I was going to have neoadjudavant chemo so no nodes were being checked surgically prior but all the doctors and tests showed that probably there were no nodes involved (there weren't).  I had neo dose dense 4xAC+4xT.  Both of my tumors were HR+ Her2-.  I had a complete pathological response on the larger tumor-no evidence of it at all after surgery.  The other tumor, which was smaller and did not worry me as much for some reason, turned out to be a warrior and shrank to 1.2 but did not disappear completely.  The onc and BS were pleased with this and said I had to consider that 1.2cm is really small.  Bottom line is it worked.  Whether it was the AC or the T or both, it worked on my hormone positive BC.  Another BC friend of mine had a 6cm+ tumor and had the same characteristics and treatment except she had ACT everytime ended up with a 5mm tumor....very small.  Just a couple of positive stories to share.  Hope I did not intrude and wish the best to all! :) edited for grammar
Posts.Title: Why do you love and hate the statistics? JudyO PatMom

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 06:56PM nene2059 wrote: ihatescreennames-so sorry to hear that you will be joining out sisterhood.  It is a great place to be once you are here but none of us really wanted to become a member:) I was diagnosed in January at age 36.  Now I am done with chemo, surgery, and in December reconstruction.  What a difference some time makes.  You will be in fight mode once you come out of shocked, scared sh##less mode.  You will get lots of info from the doctors bring it all here and allow others to help you through each step and answer questions. Lots of support on here.  Best wishes as you start this journey and take lots of deep breaths.  We are here.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2009 09:06AM nene2059 wrote: Hey Diva.  Glad I could be of some help and will continue to be I promise! I remember how busy Dr. Brackett's office kept me with all of the tests and it was all worth it.  My tumor was not large and my staging was 1 in the left breast, which was found only when Dr. Brackett did my first MRI, and 2a in the right but after 3 chemo treatments he did an ultrasound and they were gone.  I had 8 treatments all together.  We did the chemo up front and dose dense (closer together) because of my age.  My husband loves Dr. Brackett too.  He is intense and the anxiety meds will help (as they do with everything!) but make sure you always take hubby, a friend, or fam member to all appointments because they will always hear things a little more clearly than us! They can help ask questions too which helped me out a lot. You are going to be very overwhelmed and let your wonderful aunt (who may just have saved your life-you owe her a great dinner out!) and your husband (anal is good in this instance!) help you make sense of it all.  I had an MRI guided biopsy, CT Scans, genetic testing, and most other tests done right at Dr. Brackett's Imaging Center.  All of the techs, nurses, everyone there was sweet and caring. Let them help you. Dr. B will not waste too much time before he gets you started into treatment. Call his nurse educator Sabrina with any questions....I wore her out with them (mostly in tears) in the beginning.  I promise once he gets a plan in place Dr. Brackett will be giving you big hugs.  Also, there is a group of young women here that are young survivors and when you are ready let me know and an email will go out to them and they will answer any questions you have and will give support.  Welcome to the sisterhood that none of us wanted to join but are now so grateful that it exists and is STRONG! I'm here as are many others.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2009 05:54PM nene2059 wrote: I  was 36 as well when I was diagnosed in January of this year.  It is a horrible time when you are first diagnosed and when you first come here you feel like you are so far behind because of all the other information every one here seems to know.  You will know all of it too and most likely very soon.  I had chemo before surgery and if your tumor turns out to be large they may use that to shrink it before surgery which may make lumpectomy possible when it wasn't before the chemo.  I had a very good response to chemo and although they found cancer in both of my breasts after my first MRI I had one tumor disappear and the other shrink to very little.  This is an approach that more doctors are taking especially in younger women and may be an option for you.  CT scan, MRI and physical examination by the doctors can typically be pretty concise in diagnosing node involment and staging.  That was the only drawback to doing chemo first....you don't know your exact stage until after surgery.  I will say they were right on though with my clinical staging.  A biopsy should be the first thing that they do and will give much of the information that you see underneath most of the posts on here.  It will tell you type, grade, receptor status.  It is extremely tough and exhausting to tell everyone in your life the info so I recommend you set up a free website at caringbridge.org.  You post and your friends and family can respond and keep up to date with what is going on.  A nurse told me about it after my first chemo and it was a godsend.  Every one got the information at once and updated as I learned more and it became a very supportive, social connection for friends and family. They will feel included and you can conserve your much needed energy.  As for you, this site is amazing.  I learned so much from the women (and men) on here and I had new questions for my onco every appointment.  Don't stress yourself about the lingo on here, ask what it means if someone posts something you haven't seen (there are no stupid questions) and before you know it you will be using it as well.  Lots of moms are on here too and can give you great advice on how to explain it all to your kids.  Take a deep breath (and keep breathing) and get into fight mode.  Choose the sites that you visit carefully because you do not want to get bad information that will just scare you.  I have received great information and support here.  So sorry that you had to join us but hopefully you will come to see that there are some positive things that come out of a terrible diagnosis.
Posts.Title: 36, dx 6 days ago and so many questions... Melanie36 melissa-5-19

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2010 10:49PM nene2059 wrote: I had two tumors, one in right breast and one in left breast.  I had neo adj chemo 4ACx4T .  After my 3rd treatment I could no longer feel my larger tumor and my surgeon did an ultrasound and could not see it.  After my BMX there was "no residual malignancy", in other words it was gone.  The smaller tumor in the left breast had shrunk but not had not completely gone away, still a good response.  Having chemo first is great because you get to see and feel it working (or not working if that is the case).  Chemo works very quickly and I was thrilled with my result.  I believe that it does start killing those little suckers from the first treatment.  I did not do it first to get a better surgical option because I knew from the get go that at my age and cancer in both breasts I was only going to be comfortable with a BMX.  I love my reconstruction, though.  Obviously chemo worked for me and I am glad that I got to see (and feel) it myself.  Good luck with your treatment and best wishes for a great response!
Posts.Title: how realistic Polyana melania

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2009 06:27PM nene2059 wrote: Hi Beth7!  I had neoadjudavunt chemo as well and after my surgery I had confirmation that a tumor disappeared as well.  I had a much smaller tumor in the other breast that shrank but did not disappear but all of this showed that the chemo worked!  Without doing it first we would not have know that and that does give me some piece of mind.  I did not have any affected lymph nodes but now neither do you!  If you have some concerns on the accuracy of the MRI ask for an ultrasound.  My surgeon did this periodically during my chemo and it was amazing to look at the screen with him and see NOTHING! They are easy and don't expose you to radiation.  From the sounds of it it appears that you have not had surgery yet.  That is the definitive way of knowing but from the sounds of it you are having a great response and should find a lot of comfort in that. Be optimistic!  A complete pathologocal response is amazing! God bless and big hugs, Jenn

Screw his day off....get what you need.  His life will go on just the same. Take care of you.

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2009 08:42AM nene2059 wrote: Dear Little Bro and Family, I am so heartbroken for your family that Heidi's journey is coming to an end.  I am including this poem because I think it is beautiful and will apply to everyone one day.  I hope that it gives you some comfort. Though, as you stated you believe,  her time left may be short I know that it is precious and every I love you said will hold a special place in your heart. Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there, I do not sleep. I am in a thousand winds that blow, I am the softly falling snow. I am the gentle showers of rain, I am the fields of ripening grain. I am in the morning hush, I am in the graceful rush Of beautiful birds in circling flight, I am the starshine of the night. I am in the flowers that bloom, I am in a quiet room. I am in the birds that sing, I am in each lovely thing. Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there. I do not die. Feel the love of everyone here surrounding you all. Jenn
Posts.Title: Heidi Update-it isn't pretty Heidi_Ho zeeka71

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 09:19AM nene2059 wrote: Lil Bro and family and friends, thank you once again for showing such generosity and courage by coming here and updating us on Heidi's condition.  It must be so difficult for all of you and yet you summon the strength to come here and share the most personal, painful moments that your family is sharing.  You must know by now that your sister (and all of you) have touched many lives.  It  has reminded me that it is not how long you live but that you made your time here matter.  Heidi clearly achieved that and that will be the legacy for her children and all of you.  I am also happy to hear that she is not in pain.  I know that all of you are feeling tremendous pain though and for that I am profoundly sorry.  God bless you and continue to give you strength.

Posts.Title: Heidi's Memorial Service - October 12, 2009 elizzim AnnaM

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2010 07:38PM nene2059 wrote: There are definitely no stupid questions here and this is a valid concern.  I will tell you how it happened for me and hope that helps.  After my 2nd round my hair came out in balls or handfuls.  There was no pain when you it came out but I could run my hands through my hair and would have a handful.  It was not traumatic for me and of course I knew it was coming.  I had cut my hair short before chemo as well.  So when it started to come out, and if you let it go it will be on your pillow when you wake up in the morning, will come out in the shower when you wash your hair and will be all over your clothes.  I did not want this slow approach and headed back to the hairstylist who I thought was going to be the one to take it all off but when we got to a pixie cut he said "let's leave it for a few days and then when it gets worse we will shave it".  A few days later there were bald patches so my husband and I went into the bathroom and did the big shave.  I was so glad that it was he and I in that moment.  He loved it bald and thought I looked beautiful and I had about 2-3 days of OMG I look like a cancer patient and then I adjusted and was fine.  For me the shedding was going to be more traumatic then just getting it off so I felt like the "rip the bandaid" approach was mentally better for me.  If you decide to let it fall out on its own then you will see it everywhere.  Brush and comb definitely.  All of the hair does not come out though. There is still a bit of fuzz as you go through treatment.  It is not really visible in pictures or anything but you will see it.  Don't forget that you are going to lose hair EVERYWHERE.  So don't be shocked although it sure does help to not have to shave your legs or wash your hair when you are fatigued from a treatment.  To answer your very first question I was told to expect the hair to fall out after treatment #2.  I had dose dense chemo so that was pretty soon for me.  Hope all this helps.  Hang in there and remember it does grow back and is so healthy.  Just remember all the bad hair days when you felt like shaving it off and starting over....here is your chance:)  Best wishes and stay strong.
Posts.Title: How does the hair start falling? melania lago

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 11:15PM nene2059 wrote: I would like to add my prayers.  Standing beside you all in support for all of the amazing people on this site especially BCmomof 3. Jenn
Posts.Title: May God Bless BCMomOf3 heatherbless BarbaraA

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 09:38PM nene2059 wrote: I did neo-chemo too.  I did dose dense 4AC and 4Taxol.  I had bilateral BC.  I found a lump in my right breast and MRI found another, separate primary in my left.  The right was the bigger of the two and it was a little bigger than 2cm.  So I did not have a large tumor that needed to shrink nor did I have any obvious nodal involvement but my BS is a big believer that stats are going to show that neo is statistically better than adjuv. I don't know about all that but I can tell you that feeling and seeing that the chemo is working is huge mentally and helps me to worry less about mets because I know that my tumors responded to the chemo and they were both hormone pos, HER2 neg. My right tumor went away completely and the left shrank so I could of had two lumpectomies but I chose BMX because they were both producing cancer and I was 36.  I did not have nodal involvment and did not have to do radiation, yea!! The studies that have been done suggest that survival is the same for chemo given before or after so the hard part the way I see it is that neo goes against our urge to "get the cancer out".  We want the tumors gone right away and feel that leaving them in will cause them to grow or travel.  If you can get past that it was the right way for me to go.  I am confident in that I know the chemo worked (not that I don't worry about mets because I do, I think we all do) and that helps to calm the stress a little. Good luck!!
Posts.Title: neo-adjuvant chemo 1marmalade1 toni30

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 07:12PM nene2059 wrote: I don't think your attitude is crazy either.  I had what others that have not had BC or any type of cancer would describe as a hellish year.  The lump finding, the first mammo, the biopsy, the diagnosis, the MRI and CT scans, the dreaded MRI guided biopsy and then a second diagnosis (two breasts-two breast cancers), 8 presurgery chemo treatments, bilateral mx, expander fills that killed my back, Tamoxifen resistant, full hysterectomy, Femara, and to complete the year my implant surgery in Dec.  Good thing I was diagnosed in Jan so that I could make 09 the year I fit in as much surgery and treatment as I could handle.  You know for most of us on here a pretty typical year is what I had. I have had friends and family that have had just the biopsy and/or MRI guided biopsy with B9 results tell me how AWFUL it was that they had these needles put into their breasts and bruises for a while after.  Not to minimize anyone's pain threshold but I would gladly have stopped at the bruises for a B9 result.  I never felt defeated by this.  I had a few bad days and I don't want you to be surprised if you feel like shite physically and mentally for a few days after each chemo session, it does that to you.  I called it my chemo funk and after the steroids wore off I lost my energy and just felt "funky".  Nothing too terrible.  I learned to laugh alot during this because if it was going to happen anyway I felt like it could not have six months, a year, whatever of my life before I allowed joy back in.  I had a reaction to Compazine (anti nausea) after my first chemo treatment and ended up going to the ER.  It was a dystonic reaction which means that muscles in your body spasm uncontrollably and may make you move in a weird way.  It happened to my neck muscles and I was with my best friend and she said it looked like I was doing the funky chicken. We laughed about that even while I was waiting to be given the Benadryl that would stop the reaction.  We still tell my funky chicken story.  I have told my onc that I do not feel that this is coming back.  I do not dwell on it every minute of every day.  I do not live in fear and I do not sweat small stuff any more.  This is a early stage forum so I feel comfortable saying that I felt hopeful during my treatment and I feel confident that I did what I could to prevent reoccurrence. I know others say that they don't want to be told to be positive or that positive thinking can help "heal" them. I am not a pollyanna and I am not saying these things either.  All I am saying is that, for me, I will not let cancer control the rest of my life.  I hope that it is a blip in the radar of my life but I also feel like if it isn't and one day I am given horrible news I do not want to look back and say that I gave away all of this precious time. I know some women have told me that at first you thing about BC all day and then as time goes by it is less and less.  I am still in "treatment" and I go most hours and minutes of each day without thinking about BC.  I post on here so I obviously give it some time and still need support and guidance but I don't try to live in a bubble or under the covers in crippling fear that I had cancer.  It sucks and if this happened to a member of my family or one of my good friends I do believe that it would consume my thoughts. I have made a treaty with my body that I will do what I can to make this a one time event and not take it for granted anymore.  If I am proved to be delusional one day and the beast comes back then I will deal with it then.  For now I want to live a full life and not have a part of me always waiting for the ball to drop.  Maybe this is a luxury of the early stager but I know I worried alot more about things when I was a "no stage" and did not know I had cancer.  Give it all you got and beat it down, keep your attitude, and get on with your life.  If there is no "new normal" for you fabulous but what I consider my "new normal" is better than my old normal because I am better. I think others will follow your lead as well.  At work we have a lady who is always hot and turns the air way down and freezes us out.  I looked at her last week and said, "it is so freakin cold in here, I don't even have nipples anymore and they're hard".  Laugh or cry, at some point it is a choice.  You are fab don't change a thing.  If you check into the loony bin see if we can get a double room.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed and not Worried CoolBreeze Cisatypo

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2009 08:51PM nene2059 wrote: dcarpenter-congrats on being NED!! Love it, roll around in it,DANCE.  Best news to hear from my fellow posters.  Mich_M-thanks for the kind reply.  I do hope the worst is behind.  I hope it is not bad news for you, but if it is know,just know, that no matter what we are here for you and you will be okay.  Reach out your hand-we'll grab it.  I'll even do the "funky chicken" for you.  I seem to be good at it.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed and not Worried CoolBreeze Cisatypo

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2009 10:51PM nene2059 wrote: Hey writer.  They will follow your lead. It is ok if they freak out at first we all had family do that I believe. This is in the beginning after dx. After that they and you will get all the info on treatment and prognosis and then get on with it.  If you are ok they will be ok.  To be honest I complained so little during all the crap that is treatment that I feel like I am paying for it a little now.  Especially at work.  Everyone thinks I had a head cold I believe because I have found that if someone has cramps we are getting them a cake and a get well card and they treat me sometimes like I was out of work "finding myself" in Europe or something while in actuality I was" finding" my bald head and  bone loss and reconstructed boobies.  This is not your question though, sorry about that, what I am trying to say is that if you are ok your family will regroup and be fine too.  Laugh, cry, feel whatever you need to during this but don't let the months that you are in treatment go by without finding joy.  I am not a parent so I think that may be a more complex situation then just smiling to make them feel better.  Of course they will worry about you like crazy but seeing you being as normal as possible will made everyone relax. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed and not Worried CoolBreeze Cisatypo

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 09:36PM nene2059 wrote: I know I will miss someone that I wanted to send a shout out to because this thread has such great posts (and a great response) we all were obviously just waiting for it! Mamaq-Prayers for you. I am sure that it is nothing.  We all have been down this road before and hit the cancer lottery but most things found are benign.  Most breast lumps too but you would never know it to visit us here.  Best wishes to you. Laura- I was node neg too and both my onc and BS thought no radiation but I told them to make me an appointment with the radiation onc. and let him be the decisive voice.  That is his gig.  Ultimately he made the same decision and explained to me the protocol.  If there is some "gray" area for your doc on this ask to see a radiation onc to a final vote. You don't want to miss anything but you also don't want to do anything unnecessary that may cause harm. I felt the same way you do about throwing it all at the cancer but I did feel confident that chemo, surgery, and hormonals would do the trick without the rads. Made my PS VERY happy:) Coolbreeze-Officially welcome to the Stage 1&2 thread!  Good luck with chemo.  It is tough but very doable. Something that helped me was to cut my hair short the week after my first treatment and then when it started to come out in droves my husband and I went into the bathroom and buzzed it off.  It felt great to have some control over that. First couple of days after were hard but then I totally got into the baldness.  My husband loved it and I had a few pictures done.  I always covered my head when in public but at home I was bald all the time.  It really helps not to have to worry about your hair when you're tired from the chemo.  Now people stop me all the time and say that they love my hair "cut" and I always say this is hair "growth"!  Best wishes as you get chemo organized and, as you feel yucky from it, envision it going in and destroying any little suckers that the surgery did not get. Anyone else on here do neoadjudavant chemo?  I did and feel like mentally it was good for me because I could see that it was shrinking the tumors.  Of course I also worried that leaving the tumors in could be causing things to travel.  Completely unwarranted fear but you know how this thing plays with your mind.  I do still feel for lumps and bumps even though my expanders are really all I feel.  I do check my chest and collarbone because I saw my onc doing that.  Hope to never feel anything.  I felt the lump in my right breast and that it what started my journey. I found out that I had cancer by going to the surgeon after my mammo(my first) and u/s and upon first meeting him he said (not hello)," I am 99.9% certain this is cancer".  "The radiologist did not like it and I don't like it".  He said "if it comes back as anything else I will be shocked".  He then proceeded to do my biopsy while his nurse wiped my tears.  After he left the room I started to sob to my best friend who was there with me.  I made her call my hubby.  I made him call my parents.  I could not break the news to anyone.  I don't think I really believed it.  It may sound like the BS was a real jerk but he said "I will not lie to you now so that you will trust me in the future".  He did not lie and I do trust him and love him.  He is the best.  He gives his patients his cell number and actually answers it any time.  What doctor does that? Anyway nothing like having the bandaid ripped off to get you started on cancer treatment! Stage 1&2 thread rocks.
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 11:04PM nene2059 wrote: Hey dogsaver love the picture of the doggies as your avatar.  I have two little kittie princesses in my house but I am a huge animal lover and I kid all of my friends that I watch more dog shows than any dog owner (dog whisperer, dogs with jobs..just about anything doggie).  I have had many dog loves of my life and miss them terribly.  My hubby had one of our cat babies when we me met and we got another together.  I could never have made it through chemo or recovery from surgery without them,  I never napped alone!:) I am in the process of trying to get a hold of two strays in my neighborhood and have enlisted friends to help.  I am now carrying dog food and treats in the car at all times to make sure that they eat everytime I see them.  I am hoping to get them to the humane society this weekend if they will let me close enough. Their thinness and sad eyes kill me.  Anyone know who you can call to get help with this? I don't think the ASPCA is in my area and don't know what animal control does. I don't want to save them only to have them put down by animal control.  Anyway I am rambling about non BC stuff but your picture is precious.

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2010 01:46AM nene2059 wrote: PatMom I don't know about any particular studies on adjuvant chemo but I am sure they are out there.  I had neoadjuvant chemo so I saw and felt my tumors shrinking and when I had my surgery they were gone.  I don't know what impact this has on future metastasis but if chemo had that effect on the tumor cells then I can only imagine, and hope, that it had the same effect on any circulating cancer cells not attached to the tumor, assuming there were any.  Having chemo before surgery was mentally difficult because the first instinct is to say get this out of me but in retrospect it allowed me to see just what benefit chemotherapy was giving me.  A personal decision, to be sure, whether to chemo or not, and my response may not answer your question but I thought it may lend some insight from a neoadjuvant perspective. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2009 08:55AM - edited Sep 13, 2009 08:59AM by nene2059 Dear Heidi, little bro, and family, I have not posted on this thread before but have been following the updates and praying for recovery and peace for the entire family.  I am deeply saddened to hear the latest news and shocked as I truly believed that the treatment would work.  Heidi has been a brave warrior and I pray now for a miracle or if GOD has other plans....serenity for the entire family.  I have all of my friends praying for you all at church tomorrow.  Heidi's story could be anyone's at any time but being Breast Friends makes it feel that much more personal to us.  We share with you all of the love that can be sent long distance as well as healing energy, prayers, what ever we may call it. Heidi and all of the stage IV ladies and gentlemen have truly shown me how to live with courage and dignity.  I have found many lessons in their posts.....thank you. God bless you as you go through this most traumatic time, Jenn

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 09:58PM nene2059 wrote: Hi kcorbin!  I am sorry that you have to join us and I know that you are in the too shocked to really believe it phase but welcome and now you start to kick into "fight this thing" phase and collect information.  I was diagnosed in January of this year at age 36.  I had a bilateral mastectomy the day after I turned 37.  When I first visited this website I felt so far behind because everyone here seemed to know so much more about breast cancer than I did. I learned alot and so will you.  Do not go to any doctors appointments alone if you can help it because you need someone to ask questions and hear what the doctors are saying because you won't process it all.  You need to find out staging, treatment options, receptor status, etc as soon as you can and the doctors should be scheduling tests and scans at this point.  The BRCA 1&2 genetic testing is just a part of that.  I had instant reconstruction with tissue expanders with the mastectomies and I woke up with "breasts" which was great emotionally.  I am almost at the end of the recon journey and will have my implant exchange in December.  You need to focus on finding out as much about your cancer and your options for treatment right now (for example if you need chemo I had chemo before surgery and that may be an option to explore as some docs do it first and some still go for surgery first but you need to know your OPTIONS). Take notes, take someone to appointments, and BREATHE.  That is all we can really do.  Good luck and best wishes on your journey to becoming a survivor and a thriver.
Posts.Title: What happens after a mastectomy? mejustme09 mejustme09

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2009 11:21PM nene2059 wrote: Hi PureE.  I was just looking through the active threads and saw your thread and when I read your post my heart broke for you.  I can understand all the feelings you are having right now and know that they are very normal.  Anyone in your position with a fear of uncertainty would be feeling the same way.  In fact so many women on here are moms and even though they were not pregnant when they found out they had BC I know they had the same fears that you have now.  I am sure you have been trying to be strong through all of this and if you feel like having a good cry right now let it out.  BC took away my chance to become a mom and I hope through all of this fear and crap that you are going through right now you will allow yourself some quiet time where you clear your mind for awhile and don't fear the future and just "be" with your unborn baby.  The future will take care of itself even though it does not feel that way right now.  You have every reason to live free of BC as any of us.  New treatments are coming out all of the time that lead us closer to a time where we will be without (hopefully) BC.  As my onc put it each year you survive is another year of research and development.  Enjoy these moments of your pregnancy even though you and your baby have to share your body with the BC tx.  It is not fair and you should never be made to feel that it is.  I wanted a baby so badly and my hubby and I had been trying for a few years.  Who knew that I would not meet the man I wanted to marry until I was 30 and marry him at 32?  Who knew that at 36 I would be diagnosed with BC in both breasts?  Who knew that I would not be able to metabolize Tamoxifen and would be having a complete Hysterectomy a week later? No one could have predicted and I would not have believed them if they did.  That was not fair but it is different because I really can not miss something that I never had and I would have liked the opportunity but there are other ways to become a mom.  For you, it is here and now.  You will get through this and will be over joyed at your precious little life.  Hopefully it will reaffirm that there is meaning to life and you will be around to enjoy many wonderful moments with this baby and all of your family. There are so many horrific moments on the BC journey and you are more than entitled to yours so cry, scream whatever you gotta do.  Then don't mourn the loss of you and arrange the future of your family just yet..you are still here.  You are here and you will be.  This strong little soul inside of you will come out just fine and then you will take over your body and defeat this BC.  Look at how strong you already are.  You will be a great mom to this little one and what a privelege it will be to have you, survivor you, as his mommy as it is for all of your children.  I am sending you loads of positive energy and am saying prayers of strength for you tonight.  I hope you don't mind if I pop in to this thread every now and then to check on your progress.  I can't wait to hear about your joy when you meet your healthy new baby.  Congratulations, not condolences, are in order.  Stay strong.
Posts.Title: Pregnant with Breast Cancer Pure DCMom

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2009 10:27PM nene2059 wrote: Hey JeanneG!  I have become a little nervous of posting on threads that do not match my exact diagnosis and I was not stage 3 but I did do chemo first and will always be happy I did.  I had bilateral BC with a Stage IIa in the right breast (the lump I felt) and then another primary tumor was found in my left during an MRI. Bilateral mastectomy was my decision right away even though the BS said that he could probably do two lumpectomies but was concerned that at 36 both of my breast were creating hormone positive breast cancer.  I also knew that chemo was a definite and I got three opinions and all said that doing it first would be the best option.  I ended up having the larger tumor shrinking to the point of no longer being visible on ultrasound after three treatments and after surgery it was confirmed that I had a complete pathological response with that tumor.  The left tumor shrank to almost nothing but had not completely disappeared.  The piece of mind that that gave me is invaluable.  It does not guarantee no reoccurrence but it sure felt great to know that the chemo was working...something I would not know for sure if it had been done after surgery.  I also had dose dense chemo but that was based on my age and I had no other health conditions that may compromise my counts rebounding.  I had 8 treatments total. 4ac/4taxol.  I know that studies suggest that there is no difference in survival of you do it before or after but I can not describe the elation I felt when I would check my lump (I could only feel one) and it just felt like a normal breast again.  I hope the same for you and a speedy trip through chemo with great results and very little SE's.  I know all treatments react differently with different people but I just wanted to start you on your treatment journey with a positive story.  Good luck, big hugs,and best wishes.
Posts.Title: adjuvant vs neoadjuvant vs surgery JeanneG Annaanne

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2009 01:54PM nene2059 wrote: I did the Neulasta shot all eight times and I am happy to say that I did not have any side effects from it at all.  I have heard such horror stories from others about the body/bone aches but my chemo nurse told me to take one Aleve or Advil and one Claritin an hour before the shot and that did the trick for me.  If you are getting dose dense they will probably have to give it to you to keep you on schedule.  Try the Aleve+Claritin combo if they decide to give you the shot and see if that helps.  Best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: neo-adjuvant chemo 1marmalade1 toni30

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 08:18PM - edited Nov 5, 2009 08:20PM by nene2059 Hi Prihode-wow did we have similar diagnosis!  I had a 2cm tumor in my right breast and a 1.6cm in my left.  Did the neo and after surgery I had a complete path response on the bigger tumor and shrinkage to about 1.2cm on the left. Needless to say I was thrilled.  I hope to give it credit on my five year cancerversary as well.  I hope to be there with you NED.  I also had a complete hysterectomy but only because I was a Tamoxifen poor metabolizer but I am happy now that I did it.  Get rid of the estrogen!  I am on Femara and have been happy with SE's so far. Don't care I will stay on it forever as well.  Totally NOT missing my periods! I haven't had one since my first chemo treatment in Feb. and have adjusted really well to skipping the tampon aisle.  My hubby loves that "crazy woman" does not appear once a month:) If I had a node I would have insisted on rads too.  Congrats on your five years out. Your my new role model! Nancy-love the t-shirt idea.  Forgot about not being able to wear deodarant for mammo's.  Certainly a time that you need it!  Hopefully all will be clear this year for you.  Do bilateral mx's have to have mammos?  I have heard different reports on here and was hoping that the surgery meant no more of those. azdiva-have a safe, fab trip!  Enjoy some sunshine and margaritas.  I know all of this has made me appreciate all the little things so much more. Have fun creating special memories.  After all of this treatment it should be mandatory for insurance to pay for a week away some where.....maybe covered under the mental health coverage?  I would be willing to take a therapist with me if that would get it covered!  Have fun. Best wishes to all and hope everyone is well. edited for spelling issues-chemo brain still!
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 12:31AM nene2059 wrote: Valeriekd-thanks girl. Totally agree on the wackiness of BCP's today.  Periods are natural.  Not fun but natural.  Also agree about the hormones in food.  I was already trying to watch that before BC but now I am really paying attention and the amount of crap in our food is criminal.  No wonder ten year old girls look eighteen. Scary stuff.  I do think the number of younger women getting BC is on the rise.  I know when I was diagnosed I was told it was still something like 5% but I know so many under 40's that are BC veterans.  Seems like there are plenty on these boards.  I know that there are no definitive links to lifestyle and BC like there are with lung cancer but it almost seems like that would make it easier, don't do this and you won't get BC.  That would make you feel like you had SOME control. Guess that is why I don't hate pink or any of the things sold that give profits to research.  Let's find out why our genes went crazy.  Wow I sound preachy......about to throw in politics and religion so we can all sit around and feel uncomfortable. After all the in-fighting on these boards recently I thought I was gonna have to start typing while wearing brass knuckles.  Just joking of course...I come here to support and be supported. Thanks again.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2009 08:19PM nene2059 wrote: Wow this thread is fabulous.  I read all of the posts and find a piece of me in them which is nice.  Not to take anything away from the other threads but it is nice to say I had CANCER too and I am MAD and SCARED and HOPEFUL without feeling (and these are only my feelings, I do not pretend to speak for anyone else) that I am not grateful enough because I had an early stage cancer or my nodes were negative or I am not going through the hell that I know some others are experiencing.  As of now I am not in constant fear that it will take my life but cancer has taken many things from me and yet it has also given me a perspective that I would not change.  I have given cancer my breasts, I had cancer in both so both had to go.  I am replacing them with brand spankin new ones but some days as I get dressed or I am typing on my computer at work and I feel a little expander movement I remember that I have these incredibly hard fake things in my chest.  I have to say that maybe I was not as attached to my breasts as some people are because I hear people say that they mourned the loss very much and even though it was not fair to have to undergo such a drastic surgery I survived and moved on.  I gave cancer my hair for awhile and thought about how unfair it was to be told you have cancer and then it was going to make you bald but I found out that bald was not that bad and I survived and moved on.  I gave cancer my innocence that this happens to other people but not young healthy people like me.  Now I know that it does happen to people like me and I am not so special that bad things aren't going to happen to me.  I realize that I need to live with less worry and fear and be present and show up for life and the people that I care about.  Unfortunately I was not a live in the moment kind of person and was always worried about something.  Now I think when something happens...at least it is not cancer. I found that I had a strength that I did not know was there and when the diagnosis came I was able to put on my big girl panties and meet the challenges and questions about my future head on.  See that is something that I might not have posted elsewhere because after all of the tests and treatments etc. my news and prognosis were pretty good.  Not guaranteed just good right now.  Nevertheless it was hard and I was scared.  The worst thing cancer took from me was the ability to have a biological child.  My husband and I had been trying and then I found the lump and life took another direction.  Children were still a possibility until I found out that I was a poor Tamoxifen metabolizer.  Then I had it all taken out, ovaries, uterus, the works.  I had to go into menopause so that I could go on an AI.  This was devastating.  I was taking away something that we both wanted so badly and I often scan the posts of the women of all stages on this site and so many are blessed with children.  I will never experience pregnancy, childbirth, looking at my child and saying we have the same eyes or nose or we do this the same.  This was something all my life I took as a given as something that I would experience.  I had to make a choice not to be bitter when I heard of some teenager getting pregnant completely unprepared for the blessing that people take for granted or if I heard on the news that a baby was abandoned or abused.  I decided, again, that I was not so special that things were always going to be easy and in order to live a complete life I was going to have to accept that bad things happen and it was not all going to be fair.  I survived this too and I moved on.  On to adoption, fostering, maybe realizing that we are meant for some special little person that just doesn't share our dna but could share our lives.  I also realized that, for me, things could have been worse.  Instead of remaining mad I had to find the gratitude that I may have had to start the process of saying goodbye if things had gone a different way.  That would be a tragedy to me. I hope to never experience that but I have now realized that the fact that we are all going to die at some point is a reality and not some distant truth.  I feel like now is the time to make it matter. Sorry that this post is so long and  this is by far the most that I have shared on these boards.  I am not some shiny, happy person who always sees the positive I just wanted to share my journey.  I made a decision that all things being equal I have absolutely no control over my having a reoccurence so I will not waste my time worrying about it.  My grandmother had breast cancer 41 years ago and is 88 now.  I can promise you she will die of something else.  I said to my onc well I guess I will have to wait 41 years to be able to say that and he said what would you get out of wasting that much time on worry.  At Stage 1&2 we stradle the fence on having this again but have the luxury of being able to be hopeful that we have seen the last of it. Some of us will progress to mets or a reoccurence but the vast majority will not.  Some of us will die in a plane or car crash but the vast majority will not.  Same odds. Today we survive and move on. Best wishes to all.
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2009 08:37PM nene2059 wrote: Lassie and Athena-I know what you mean about the Dr. visits.  I have gotten to the point where I just assume that an appointment will come with pain.  Somebody will be coming at me with a needle is almost a guarantee.  I did chemo without a port so I guess part of that is my fault for agreeing that I could do without but I have thought that it is not right that we get this illness and then get tortured for a year (or more).  Guess that is why none of my doctors had any problems giving Xanax.  Maybe they needed a few too.  Great to hear you feel a little better Athena.  Leah-Have a wonderful trip and hopefully wherever here in the States you are going is WARM:) Rumoret-thanks for starting this thread.  I thought about a support group too but couldn't really find one.  This is a great alternative. CoolBreeze-hope you end up with cancer in mod.  No post deleting necessary...grab a microbrew and tell us how you are feeling.  I am also of the POV that we did not do anything to cause our cancer.  I asked my onc (and BS,PS, everyone) if I did anything to cause this and my onc, who is YOUNGER than me said maybe it was the big old microwaves we got in the '80's and I said no it had to be my Atari game system.....too much Pong and Pacman playing as a kid!
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 06:55PM nene2059 wrote: Kayec, I thought I would post to let you know that what you are dealing with is very common and normal during this process.  It seems like your recon has had some setbacks but one it will get completed and you will be so happy with it.  I had moments during all of my treatments where I felt down and like the other ladies have said you have to take little moments and do some things that give you comfort.  Eat that ice cream, buy a juicy book, get that pair of boots that make you feel fabulous.  Also, do have a few other BC sisters that you can call or meet for coffee?  I did not go to a "support group" but I ended up with friends of friends that reached out to me and I had a few different ladies that I could talk to when things were low and I knew that they would understand.  I really do think that our families and non-bc friends can not deal with going to a fearful place in their minds so they act as if nothing is wrong.  They will follow your lead, I believe, and if you let them know that you are struggling a little some of them may be glad that they can finally do something for you.  I think we all keep stiff upper lips while going through all of this crap.  Some days you just need to yell, "I have freakin cancer and I need some attention". Best wishes to you and be gentle with yourself during this trying time.  It does get better I promise.  xoxo
Posts.Title: Down in the dumps kayec mari65

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2010 08:33PM nene2059 wrote: Chemo, Chemo, Chemo  Yunlee!! I was 36 at diagnosis (37 now) was stage IIa, no node involvement, and my tumor was about 2cm (maybe a little bigger) and it was no question at all for my surgeon and onco that I was absolutely getting chemo.  My grade was 2.  I had chemo first, in fact.  My larger tumor (I had a smaller one in the other breast) disappeared COMPLETELY with the chemo.  I had bilateral mastectomy and of course this was after chemo so I did not have an Oncotype DX but I can not imagine a doctor telling a young woman not to do chemo.  I know some on here may disagree that I am so chemo on this, and I do believe it is a personal decision and not necessary in every case, but you are young and they should be throwing everything at it.  I did not have radiation because I had the bilateral and no nodes and I was comfortable with that especially with the hormonal meds.  Please get a second opinion and I think that you will get a very different recommendation.  Chemo does not come without its own set of side effects and problems and if we were 77 maybe the decision to not do chemo would be of consideration but not for someone our age.  Throw everything that you feel comfortable with at it and do not let someone in a lab coat make life decisions for you.  I determined a long time ago that if I did not advocate for myself (and luckily I have not had to much with my drs) and something happened to me it would really be horrid for my loved ones but my doctors' lives would go on just as before. Good luck with everything and let us know what you decide.
Posts.Title: StageIIA, Oncotype 17- NO CHEMO, Are you Agree? yunlee72 ColoGal
